I'll see your moral dilemma and raise you a moral dilemma: of those 30,000 Americans who are killed on the road every year, 1/3 of the deaths involve alcohol. That's right: literally one in three Americans killed on the road are killed by drunk drivers, or are drunk drivers. The vast majority of those could be prevented if cars had a safety interlock that required the driver to prove they were sober (such as with a breathalyzer).
Another third are killed due to "distraction", which we all know means talking on the phone, texting, etc. The vast majority of those could be prevented if cars had a safety interlock that prohibited outgoing voice or SMS messages while the car was in motion, and if cell phones were built to be compatible with this system.
So if the goal is saving lives, it would be far more economical to simply add two safety interlocks to all cars (and retrofit them to existing cars), and it could be done NOW, not 5 or 10 years from now.
So why don't we do that?

But you left out the real ethical questions, here.
1) If there are both human-driven cars and self-driving cars on the road, and there is an accident, the courts will certainly view the tech through the same rose colored glasses as technophiles and assume the human driver is at fault - unless the evidence is overwhelming to the contrary. It will become the default assumption. This means in practice that everyone will HAVE to get a self-driving car as soon as they become common, no matter how much they may like and enjoy driving themselves.
2) If I'm in a self-driving car and it hits and kills a kid, who is liable? It's my car, after all. I SHOULD have psychically seen the peril in the situation and taken over, right? I probably had to sign something to that effect when I bought the thing; any failure is actually my responsibility as the owner of the car. So I'm responsible for something I had no real control over. But of course I can CLAIM that the fault lies with the car. So who gets sued? The dealer? The manufacturer? The programmer? The question becomes: in the chain of people who could be culpable, who can least afford the best lawyers? Who can least afford to lay the groundwork for avoiding responsibility by influencing the governing legislation? Hmm. I think that would be me. Is it not predictable that everyone else would be passing the buck until it came back around to me? Self driving cars will absolutely make you responsible for something that is not in your control.
3) There will be pressure from the auto industry for everyone to go out and buy the new, patented, product to replace the stock of traditional cars on the road. Because of course, that will be profitable for them. GM went belly up and the government stepped in to underwrite them; will this pressure from the auto industry NOT lead to rent seeking? Will there NOT be corruption that expresses itself in laws to encourage and require self-driving cars (and absolve manufacturers of responsibility for problems), whatever their hiccups might actually be?
4) Most worryingly: Once everyone has self-driving cars could, say, China create a system in which if a person's social credit score is not high enough their car shuts down? Could the U.S. remotely shut down the cars of everyone who hasn't paid their auto registration fee? How about their taxes? How about people who post "misinformation" online? What about people on the terrorist no-fly list - should they not be on a no-drive list as well? The ability to algorithmically control the mobility of some undesirable subset of the populace is just a shade problematic, is it not? If the government identifies a dissident, oh, excuse me, I meant to say a criminal, would it be possible to have their car drive them to the police station? Not in the U.S., of course - our government is fully committed to avoiding Orwellian behavior and would never do such a thing, obviously. That's just crazy talk. But in OTHER countries, would this be the technological advance we're looking at?

The real issue with self-driving cars is not the car itself, but that they need other cars on the road to be autonomous as well to function safely without the need of human supervision, and I am just scratching the surface of this topic.

Many years ago, I was driving along the Nimitz Freeway, I-880, near San Leandro CA. Suddenly, a truck wheel appeared right in front of me, rolling towards me. It was impossible for me to react, much less figure out how to react. The end result was me hitting the wheel square on, vaulting me up in the air and landing, bursting all four of my tires as I skidded, luckily, to a gore point. There were no other vehicles to the sides of me, but other cars did come up behind me several seconds later.

Had this been an autonomous an autonomous vehicle, (a) it would have been able to identify the oncoming object sooner (it was dark and rainy, but LiDAR can see through rain and zero ambient light), and (b) it would have been able to swerve properly without causing a worse rollover.

But even in the case that it couldn't, the moral decision for the AV is to protect its passengers, not the nearby motorcyclist or SUV. If I paid for the use of an AV, that AV should protect me. So, that truck that dropped something off its back will have its plates photographed and sent to the cloud. When all's said and done, that truck's liability insurance will pay for everyone injured, including either the SUV or the motorcyclist or both plus others.

For some reason youtube wanted to show this to me today, and I do think you're missing a pretty big point here. Not to say that you're wrong, I agree completely with the overall point. Autonomous cars WILL save many lives and we should have them.

The thing I think you're missing, or ignoring maybe, is that by pushing driving decisions onto a program, the responsibility for those decisions falls onto the program and not the driver. It's easy to gloss that over and say "no, the driver is still responsible" but then it's not really autonomous, is it? If it doesn't work when no one's inside, I mean. So you have to program this stuff in. Not directly, of course. There won't be a line of code that directly chooses who lives and who dies in an accident, that's a silly diversion. But a strategy and approach to accident conditions must be programmed in, that much is obvious. It will be complicated and in many ways emergent behavior from many different sensors and systems, rather than being "hard coded". But that doesn't mean it's not part of the program.

I think getting "on average" safer cars on the road is a greater imperative than fine-tuning autonomous car driving strategy in accident conditions. But both discussions can and should be had. Fairly often I see people dismiss concerns about the latter by citing the need for the former, and that's wrong. It's also wrong to stymie innovation and real safety improvements with hand-waving about moral dilemmas, but I think an intelligent discussion about the topic can be more nuanced than saying "we're making it better on average so you should stop caring about the details" which is too often the implication of titles like the one for this video.

People that consider authority as a component of morality (according to a Ted Ex talk, this moral axis is predominantly expressed in conservatives) would rather have a human make life/death decisions than an AI, because even if the human is less accurate, he has more moral authority to make that decision than an unconscious algorithm.

There are so many answers to that question... I'll try to list a few:
* Drivers aren't willing to take on legal responsibility for errors of other humans (software bugs).
* No commercially available autonomous vehicle today (2021) is capable of dealing with unexpected terrain changes: road closures, missing pavement, divergence of road and road markings, a guy halting you or waving you through, and most importantly, situation X that you've never encountered before.
* Some low-end autonomous driving systems are genuinely bad. We are assuming that all autonomous systems will be able to deal with the most basic driving conditions, but we only ever talk about high-end systems. Not all work equally well.
* There's an uncertainty in interactions between human and machine. Most people (that I know, of course) are perfectly fine with fully autonomous, contained systems, like elevators, or like the light rail systems servicing many airports around the world. There's a reason for that: humans have been interacting with each other for hundreds of thousands of years, while interactions between human and AI are very new.

In a way self driving does not make sense if there is no universal human interface, training, lack of SOPs and vehicles are mostly owned by the operators (building on the aviation analogy).

Consider the lack of consistent retraining for drivers as another factor that makes driving unsafe.

There is also infrastructure costs. The vehicle is not the only expense, the infrastructure and maintenance costs are incredibly high. These all don't not scale very well and even in aviation infrastructure is 20 years behind where it was intended to be by now (FANS) but you just adapt as an operator because you are trained.

Deskilling in aviation has to be compensated for by extra training and constant examinations and retraining. Very strict safety margins contribute significantly downgrading otherwise fatal scenarios to incidents. These are incredibly expensive and commercial aviation unlike automated driving is not pushing the limits of technology, it prioritises consistency and safety.

A Human driver is happy making the decision to put a bystander at risk, to mitigate their own risk.  A selfish survival strategy works because it invalidates all competing survival strategies.  An AI driver has to be perfectly altruistic.  It has to do the best it can without putting cars near it at any more than the absolute minimum of risk.  It cannot choose to swerve.  A selfish strategy only works for the individual, but an AI cannot be written to only consider one person.

We're in the weird zone where autonomous vehicles aren't perfectly safe, but they are safer than human-driven cars. Not to mention the fact that their safety weaknesses are different from humans. So while there are vastly more situations where an AI will make the right choice and a human will make the wrong one, there are still some situations where a human will make the right choice, and the AI will make the wrong one. (When I say "right" and "wrong" in this context, I'm talking about objective safety considerations, not ethical ones.)

There is one ethical scenario which I think is important and that is whether the self-driving car should prioritize the life of its driver vs the life of pedestrians, and the reason this one is important is because of the incentives it creates. My view here is that an individual should be incentivized to get a self-driving car as soon as possible, and with that in mind the self-driving car should prioritize the life of its owner/passengers. This means that any individual is better off with one than without even if no one else has one, and then when everyone has a self-driving car everyone else benefits even more. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts, but even each individual part is good for each individual. By contrast, if the car is designed to weigh the driver's life against the life of outsiders, while perhaps the overall benefits for everyone having a self-driving car is greater, it creates a prisoner's dilemma type scenario where for any individual, they may be better off or at least feel better off relying on their own judgement knowing that they're never going to sacrifice themself for the greater good. This creates a disincentive towards the adoption of self-driving cars.

Maybe it's not so exciting and romantic that you can tell your children about later, but isn't it better to think about what could go wrong? I prefer to be more bored and take my time making decisions rather than just storming away. The development of self-driving cars is already fast enough - before 2007 we didn't even have smartphones (in the latest definition) and 12 years later we're talking about self-driving cars. Just a little more than a decade! In addition to moral and political guidelines, technological problems must also be mastered. All this takes time.

Incidentally, the introduction of a general speed limit is once again being discussed here in Germany. At first glance, this only seems logical, because if all the other countries do it that way, it must be good, right? Not necessarily. In fact, Germany achieves similarly "good" death rates on its transport network as the comparable Spain, which is known to have a speed limit. In Germany, the motorway is one of the safest roads because there is no oncoming traffic or intersections. Of course accidents - when they happen - are always terrible and very exciting in the media, but the figures speak for themselves: despite everything they are very rare and above 100 km/h it doesn't really matter how fast you drive. An accident at these speeds almost always leads to death. The individual driving skills, the car's technology and assistant system are much more important than just the speed. There are still two other frequently quoted theses: avoidance of traffic jams and environmental protection. Well, traffic jams are not caused just by high speeds, but by irregularities and high traffic volumes. Both can be controlled much better by dynamic speed limits and possibly diversions than by a general speed limit. In fact, about 1/3 of all motorway kilometres are already limited - for various reasons. Uncertainty and choice of counterfactual need to be built into the so-called moral dilemmas. Also, the chain or tree of cause and effect is an extremely complicating factor.

For example, the counterfactual to rolling out autonomous vehicles faster might be improving other aspects of driving safety more rapidly or lower road use or improved public transport. Each of these counterfactuals can hypothetically reduce death and injury on the roads more than a given future with autonomous vehicles simply by being radical enough.

Many, many counterfactuals however unlikely are safer visions of the future or of the present for that matter.

Posing the question of a moral dilemma is perhaps aggrandizing the situation. It's possibly better to ask what is the practical next step given the present reality and constraints.

One thing about self driving cars which I think is important to consider (whether you care or not is up to you) is where the motivation for their development is coming from. What car companies tell the public vs what they tell their investors as to why it's worthwhile for them to be researching and developing self driving vehicles are two separate things. The message to the public is basically what you hear in this video - the technology has real potential to save lives (and, not mentioned, to lower emissions of transportation by decreasing traffic). Those benefits are real, and while it's certainly a benefit for businesses pursuing the technology, it's not the main reason. Obviously the main reason is profit, whatever, that's the motivation behind any business venture. The problem is that most of the profit comes from data collected on the passengers of the autonomous vehicle - data on where people are going and when, most broadly, and this information can then be sold to whomever - retailers, advertisers, marketers, product planners, financial analysts, government agencies, anyone willing to pay for it, and who can then use that information to build profiles about you. It's nothing new, it's the same thing Facebook, Google and basically every other internet business does to internet users, just with information about your physical habits rather than digital. Whether you find this collection of personal data to be an unacceptable breach of privacy or not is up to you, I don't really care. I just think it's worth thinking about.

The moral dilemma here isn't about safety. There is absolutely no doubt that self driving cars will be safer, since they remove the factors of driver error, driver impairment, and driver distraction.. There will be fewer lives lost.

The real dilemma is about how this will change our society:

1. FIVE million jobs lost (truck, cab, delivery and bus drivers).
2. More people commuting since they can sleep on their way to work.
3. More people living further from their jobs, using more fuel.
4. More traffic and congestion, as they let their cars "drive around the block" rather than paying for parking.
5. More roads needed as people who couldn't use cars now can. (Blind, elderly, infirm.etc.)
6. Less need to carpool or share rides resulting in more cars on the road.

The real problem isn't safety. It is economic and societal. Eventually, it will happen, but it will seriously change the way we do things, and those changes will have a severe impact on our lives.

My guess is that every one of those problems listed above will be solved in time. But there will be some real problems during the transition.

That's the question, whether we choose deontology or utilitarianism. For all of you who don't know, deontoloy is a normative ethical position which judges the morality of an action by pre-set rules. Most of all countries' governments are based on deontological ethic. That means, for example: You have a rule, and that rule is "You may never torture a human.", then you may never torture a human. That is also the case when the police captured a terrorist and he hid an autonomously triggered nuke in a large city. The only way you could save those many lives is by torturing the terroris to get the information, but that goes against your own rules. Utilitarianism sees that from a different perspective. According to utilitarianism, the means justify the ends, so the results are the only important thing. You may kill a person to save five others.
The things is, in my opinion, the deontological point of view is the more important one in the debate about autonomous cars. Of course, it would reduce the total amount of people killed, but only a sith deals in absolutes. Because if you have the case that the car has to decide whether it is going to crash into another car or a motorcycle, the car is going to make a decision that takes the option of death into account. It commits homocide based on calculations. And as you may never kill, a rule that most people live by, deontology says that the car shouldn't be able to get into that situation by not making it autonomous in the first place.

This is utter, utter nonsense and is distracting from the truth: Cars are not entities, they do no think, they do not feel; they only do as told by a defined program and ultimately, THE DRIVER. Limitations, clear definitions and disclaimers to what the vehicle can and cannot do, it is the driver that ultimately decides on whether or not they use the system with full knowledge that it is fallible. Despite airliners being capable of flying themselves, should an issue arise, an airplane will automatically disconnect autopilot and hand control back to the pilots. In most cases, the full responsibility falls on the pilot of the aircraft and not some black and white ethics dilemma.
The entire notion of killer AI robot cars and calling an ethics problem is nothing more than a wishful fantasy. As great as self-driving cars would be, we need to focus on the real problem: lousy, inconsiderate and irresponsible drivers that don't care about driving properly.

The comments about that specific scenario (like saying the obvious choice is keeping more following distance or swerving into the car) are missing the point. It is not about how to handle that specific scenario (if it were, it would be easy to program the solution). That scenario is just a simple way to show one out of millions of possibilities where the car might find out an accident is unavoidable, so it would have to choose the best among all the accident options. The details the cars will encounter will vary, a lot (it could be another vehicle erratically swerving into the way, a tree falling, people walking on the middle of the highway, false alarms, whatever), but there will always be these situations in which the car will have to make such difficult decisions.
There will be situations where the cars will make decisions which were not the best. But at some point, cars will be taking better decisions than humans more often than not. If cars are not self-driving, these same decisions will be taken all the time by humans, who often will make a more random decision, not having the time, data or attention to properly consider everything.
Software has many advantages, including the possibility of testing it for millions of possible difficult scenarios, way more than a human driver could ever be tested before being given a license. The cars on the road can also collect data on all accidents, which will go into a big repository to be used for testing future software.

My issue with "driverless" vehicles is not so much an issue with the type of vehicle shown and would likely buy one when affordable. The type of driverless car I have issue with is the type such as what Tesla is suggesting where there is NO command console (steering wheel, gas, & breaks) with which I can control the vehicle. First the technology is too new to be truly comfortable with, and more importantly there is the question of who is legally responsible.

If I am in a vehicle that is completely driving itself and something goes wrong (ie black ice at highway speeds causing my vehicle to crash into another vehicle killing one or more passengers in that vehicle) who is legally responsible? The car manufacturer who made the vehicle and maintains the self driving software or me as the owner of the vehicle in which I had absolutely no control over events.

On the one hand it would seem that it should be the manufacturer who is responsible not me but insurance and legal codes currently do not allow for this sort of scenario and thus I would likely be liable for an incident which I could not have stopped or altered in any way.

On the other hand, in the example used in the video of self driving elevators the owner of the building is liable for any incidents which occur on their premises not the manufacturer unless it can be proved that the manufacturer knew about an issue and did not correct it. In the current car situation I as the owner of the vehicle am liable for any damages which occur due to my vehicle even if I am not the person driving, or even in the car. so we can see that currently liability would fall squarely in the owner of the vehicle even though that owner would not have any control or way of controlling the vehicle at the time of the incident.

Until this gets worked out in a way equitable to all parties, and while I will definitely use driving and safety aides, y'all will only get my steering wheel out of my cold dead hands.

Is saving 10,000 lives a year - many of whom are killed due to their own error - worth the entire elimination of 100,000 to 1,000,000 (to many more, if you want to include industries that rely on drivers as a main source of customers, like restaurants, coffee shops, etc. particularly in rural to small urban centres between the large urban centres) fairly well paying jobs?

Is the unknown (and potentially unknowable, prior to implementation) risk of catastrophic failure of a driving network greater than the known risk of driving today? ie: someone finds a way to take control of cars remotely? Vault 7 release from Wikileaks already indicates that the CIA may have the ability to take control of cars remotely; imagine if Putin had that power and could take control of the cars driving around Congressmen or their families. Or someone connected to ISIS. Or just some random 400lb jerk in his basement out for shiate and giggles. Or a debt collection agency can simply drive a car from your lot to their lot.

What is the risk to losing that essential skill - driving - to our society, which is so dependent on goods and services moving around with precise timing? If there is a hiccup in the system (and EVERY computer system has hiccups) that causes trucks to be unable to drive, there is a real possibility that people may die due to lack of critical needs (perishable medicines for the most part) at critical times. While I agree that in theory that self-driving cars will ultimately be safer, I think that these moral dilemmas are very real challenges behind the introduction of self driving cars, and they are challenges that are not present in the case of other autonomous vehicles. Aeroplanes for example have a fairly simple hierarchy in how they operate: They will attempt in order (this may be slightly wrong but should right in main) to not stall, not crash into the ground, not run into other airplanes, and not make sudden movements which may damage the payload. That is a far more simple model than the hundreds of potential risks and threats that face a car, and with the more complex environment, comes more complex moral dilemmas as well. Planes are programmed on the theory that the safest option is to keep it under control and in the sky, and the scale above reflects that. In a car, keeping it on the road is not necessarily safer than off the road depending on the circumstances. A car programmed poorly could result in the death of more people than a human driver would have. And then who is responsible? Is it the manufacturer? the user? the owner? The safety authority who certified it. To establish that, the ethics need to be defined and controlled by the policy makers and best practice, and that needs to happen before they're released on the public, and not after a few hundred legal battles and class actions.

I disagree, and here's why:

Veritasium falsely tries to make the issue about # of lives saved, when # of lives saved is not - let me emphasize - NOT the number one priority. What we, as a society, typically value most is freedom, or autonomy.

Here's an example: Imagine we had the option to convert our society into a "police state" - universal 6pm curfew, police and government officials could, at their discretion, search anyone's home/person, detain suspicious people, and incarcerate individuals deemed "high-risk". Such a society would be undeniably "safer" than any society that currently exists. Violent crime would be nearly wiped out. Yet why does that scenario seem so terrifying? Why would the overwhelming majority of people vote against such a system, even though it maximizes the number of lives "saved"?

Because it incontrovertibly denies our right to freedom. People would rather be free than safe, and we can look to history example after example of this. Now, I'm not unilaterally against the implementation of self-driving cars. Overall I think they would be a great asset to society. But I don't think the ethical and moral implications can just be swept under the rug. And it's going to be a VERY difficult issue to reconcile. The biggest issue, I think, is going to be the "safety of the driver vs safety of everyone else" issue. How does a machine make a decision between prioritizing, say, the life of its one occupant versus the lives of a family of four in the vehicle in the next lane? The car can avoid an obstacle (such as a a mattress) that fell into the lane ahead, which could potentially result in severe injury/death to its one occupant, or it can veer into the next lane, avoiding the obstacle but colliding with the family of four, maybe running them off the road.

To anyone who says it should just maximize the number of lives, think back to my earlier example. It's not that cut-and-dried, and how we approach this issue will say volumes about the values our society holds most dear.

There is no "full autonomous mode" in modern airliners. Pilots must thoroughly understand the auto flight system and its interaction to take advantage of the automation which allows for a reduction of workload so that the pilots may concentrate towards resolving the next problem. Every airline trains its pilot to a set of standard operating procedures, in other words rules that must be followed. However, these rules come with the caveat that the Pilot in Command may deviate from these rules for interests of flight safety. It is impossible to write or program every solution for every possible situation, and I so it is left up to human creativity that must resolve these problems.
If the automation system cannot be programmed to predict or know every situation then it must be able to replicate human creativity to deal with situations outside its scope. In the absence of such a creative system there can be no full proof system (a 100 % safe system).
I'd imagine if every driver were subject to the same scrutiny as airline pilots...that is: 6 month recurrent training/retesting requirements, on going continuous training, accident investigation studies, emergency situation training, annual physical examination, all above pre employment screening... then there would be much fewer accidents on the road.

Programming a car to make decisions of weather or not a car will detect falling debris and weather or not it should swerve into a motorcycle or try to take the chance of slowing down is a non issue. People often forget or don't know that at the core, computers are flawed.  There are layers of redundancy that go into making sure your RAM is correct, or that your webpage doesn't  show up with garbled text.  Programs themselves are only programmed to handle things in advance, and any errors that aren't spotted initially will show up when it means someones life is at risk.  So the answer to one of the most popular issue that people like to think up about self driving cars is, don't program them to swerve at all, because chances are pretty good they won't do what you were hoping for them to do.

I know this got a bit long, so have a tl;dr: Most of the problems with self-driving cars are actually problems with humans, but they're still real problems that are really related to self-driving cars, and that's why they're not gonna be the norm for a good long while.

A few very big reasons there aren't more self-driving cars out there:

1) They aren't actually safer than human drivers in most situations (yet). They almost certainly will be eventually, but elevators and planes are false equivalents for precisely the reason already mentioned in the video: Cars have far more degrees of freedom than an elevator, and the opposite problem (far more obstacles) for planes. It's safer to cruise on autopilot; humans take over for takeoff and landing. Long before autonomous cars are safer than humans in all situations, they'll be safer on highways.

2) I see a lot of people complaining that there's no moral dilemma to program, but you're not quite right. The car does not care about morals, but the programmer does and has to give the cars priorities that reflect his or her morals. That is, if someone jumps out in front of a car, does it slam on the brakes and maybe injure the person less, swerve into the woods and almost certainly kill its "driver," or swerve into oncoming traffic and possibly cause even more deaths, but also possibly merely cause more injuries with no fatalities? This may be an edge case, but with millions of cars on the road, it happens every day. Moreover, there's the matter of financial responsibility: Can someone injured by a self-driving car (whether passenger, pedestrian, or another driver) sue the company that made it because the choice it made to reduce injury caused that particular person's injury? The companies designing the cars have to worry about that before they market them too aggressively.

3) You know what's way more dangerous than stupid distractable monkeys operating thousand-pound vehicles capable of reaching speeds of over eighty mph? Stupid distractable monkeys operating those vehicles while some of the cars around them are computer-operated. Computers do precisely what they're told to, and humans don't. Ironically, that makes computers unpredictable to the average human, because the computer will make the right decision most of the time, but the human might not, which means the human can't predict what the computer will do. The situation's even worse in reverse: The stupidity humans sometimes exhibit is beyond a computer's capability to calculate. This combination is likely to result in a rise in traffic accidents (especially in cities, possibly accompanied by a slight decrease in accidents on highways) during the roll-out phase of self-driving cars. Which leads us to the last part:

4) That roll-out phase is going to take decades. People aren't going to want to give up their control. People aren't going to want to shell out the extra cash. And that's just the few people who can afford new cars. I don't personally know anyone who has ever bought a new car from a dealer. In the US, at least, middle class means buying "certified pre-owned" cars from a dealer, while anyone below that buys cheap lemons from the classifieds (or Craigslist, nowadays) or from skeezy "buy-here-pay-here" used car lots. My car is fourteen years old. I know people who drive cars that are more than twenty years old. If the dealers started selling nothing but self-driving cars tomorrow, they'd be maybe half the cars on the road in ten years. I grant you, that's partly the point of this video---It's gonna take a while, so we need to start ASAP---but, given point 3, that means it's gonna get a lot less safe for a decade before it gets better. Worse, car companies that don't have good self-driving controls yet (anything cheap, pretty much) will use that fact to make it look like self-driving cars are the problem in their advertising, which will make lawmakers and insurance companies even more leery, which will force manufacturers to perfect the software even more before putting it in cars for sale.

A good point, that I think could be expanded upon, but on a different note:

Can you make sure to include percentages when using high number statistics?

For instance, 30K fatalities/year total, and 3K fatalities/year from distracted driving. That's 10%. Any time people go to internalize very large numbers, they either see only the large number and the fact that it must be impactful (if in this case they were already inclined to be anti-distracted driving), or numbers that they can't internalize, so they feel that it might be statistics being misused to unfairly persuade their opinion (for instance, if I thought that people made too big a deal about distracted driving). What's really poisonous about the 2nd scenario is that it leads to a general distrust of statistics in general.

I think both parties benefit from always knowing the % or the % difference when dealing with large number case studies. No need to remove the real value (3k), just also state that it's 3K (10%) fatalities by distracted driving. And even if it feels like your scare tactic of 3K fatalities by distracted driving seems less effective when the 10% is added next to it, I think in reality it always seems move effective (and less of a scare tactic), because it's being more honest and less persuasive.

The dilemma with getting self-driving cars faster on the road is the same dilemma companies face when they try to be the first to market in whatever product they have to offer. Often times, the first to market company's products have bugs or glitches that have been overlooked because not enough tests have been conducted to cover all issues and areas of improvement. And it's through that company's errors that the competitors gain an advantage and are able to adjust before putting their product out there. You also have to consider the risk of putting self-driving cars on the market that have not been tested as thoroughly as they could have been had there been no pressure to be first to market. Companies would face class action lawsuits from consumers that could bankrupt them. You also have to consider the harm of having dangerous self-driving cars out there, consumers would be a lot more reluctant to buy other models coming out after that. It wouldn't save as many lives in the long run as it can potentially save had companies taken their time thoroughly testing these products before putting them out on the market.

If Manufacturer A makes the choice to swerve left in a situation, but Manufacturer B makes the choice to swerve right, that could create real hazards - not just moral ones.

These choices - do you choose to risk property damage and minor injury or do you choose to splat the dog (and can your tech tell the difference between a dog and a toddler, or a ball and a cat) are real issues that must be resolved in order for the programming to be consistent in responses and for people to feel comfortable allowing the car to make decisions in these situations.

If I (as the owner of the car) choose, then that moral choice is on me. If the car chooses - the choice is still on me because I allowed the car to choose. People (generally) aren't going to abdicate the actuality of that choice and continue to bear responsibility for it if they aren't comfortable with the decision-making framework.

By definition, a program is amoral. It relies entirely on the information and decision-making framework it has been given. That's a fairly substantial leap given the lack of faith in technology (especially current self-driving technology) most people have.

Would self-driving cars save lives? Undoubtedly. But having them available won't force people to buy them - and if they aren't being bought because people don't trust them, they can't save lives. This is a problem that has to be resolved in order to facilitate getting self-driving cars on the road.

The idea of autonomous cars used to scare me. Then one day I was driving to work and glanced over to see the driver next to me changing his pants while driving! A few days after that I saw another driver reading a freaking newspaper while driving!

Those two instances crystallized in my mind the reality that most people don't like driving and would rather not do it. Sure, they love the freedom of movement it offers, but they don't like actually driving. They would rather be changing their pants, or reading a newspaper, or texting their bff, but instead they have to drive right now so they "compromise" and do those things WHILE they drive.

A computer by contrast may make slightly worse decisions in a pinch (though I'm not even convinced of this anymore), but it doesn't have anything better to do than drive. The computer driving your autonomous car will never be distracted by its pants, the newspaper, or its bff. It will pay attention to the road and only the road, and so even if its decisions are otherwise not quite as good as yours would be (which, again, I'm no longer convinced is the case) it will still have fewer accidents.

Say the car can see the different options, calculate predicted outcomes, give them something I'll call a favorability value, and chooses the option whose predicted outcome has the highest favorability. As I understand it, this is at least close to how it works. You can have many of the numbers in the programming that determine how favorable certain outcomes are be tweakable, rather than fixed. Then, you have simulations for many of these contrived scenarios, where there are choices between your life or someone else's, or choices between two cars to hit, played for the owner during a setup of the car. During the simulations, the driver picks which outcome they want so that the programming can get an estimation of what they want. For instance, it could learn from one person that, in order to prevent a potentially fatal collision, they would hit literally any other motorist, while another person might weirdly only wish to hit a pedestrian, etc. Of course, they would prevent any illegal choices.

Now, I know that is a whole different programming problem that can't be easy to implement, but I'm just talking about the conceptualization of how the solution would work

Allow me to give a possible solution to the supposed "Moral Problem" of self driving cars.

For those unaware of the conundrum it goes something like this:

"There are 3 lanes on a highway. The left lane is occupied by a car with a family, the middle lane has you the driver, and the right lane has a single person on a motorcycle. In front of you is a truck that suddenly has part of its cargo come loose and is flying towards you. The self driving car has one of 3 possible actions, it can swerve to the right colliding with the motorcyclist, killing him in the process but saving the driver. Option two is that the car swerves to the left colliding with the car with the family, possibly injuring or killing them but again saving the driver or the car can stay where it is, possibly injuring or killing the driver. What should the self driving car do"

This is one version of the "Self Driving Car Moral Issue" there are many but this is the one that i hear a lot.

The solution to this problem is easy. Have self driving cars. The idea is that the car containing you the driver can swerve either way without any danger due to the fact that at the same time the car swerves the vehicles on the left and right side can come to an emergency stop to allow the car to swerve. The network of vehicles allow for cars to communicate at nearly the speed of light (or however fast wireless information actually travels :P). From here the moral issue simply dissolves away its now a simple mechanical issue of can the cars stop in time and I am positive that we can make that a non-issue. There is however leaves the terrifying idea of an entire network of cars and the MASSIVE security risks that could pose if it were to be hacked, but that's a problem that a single dude on the internet is not going to able to solve.

If there are any serious issues to my posed solution or if I've overlooked something i would love to hear about it.

Two things:
1. No matter who is driving (person or computer), insurance companies need to charge more when there is an accident, so I see the powerless driver whose car caused an accident getting stuck with the bill. OR everyone who has a driverless car gets charged the same increased price to compensate for the occasional accidents. By the way, when someone without an autonomous car does something that causes the auto-car to have an accident, who is at fault? I can see a ton of instances where the human driver did something, then continued on their way not even knowing that an accident happened and that something might have been perfectly reasonable. The auto-car gets the blame there, sometimes correctly, sometimes not. There WILL be a long time where auto-cars will share the roads with human drivers.

2. It seems to me that we have a few driver assists already that will drastically reduce accidents, such as stopping the car when it gets too close to a car ahead that has stopped (or slowing the car so it keeps enough distance automatically), lane drift warnings, etc. As for going completely autonomous, it seems we could make them required for anyone who has been stopped for driving impaired even once (a serious expense so don't be a jerk and drive drunk or high). Also, I think we should shy away from putting people in categories such as "too old to drive". The driver assistance tech would probably solve most of that problem. Another one could be to limit the speed of the car to avoid reckless driving. So I am not saying limit the speed to the speed-limit, just avoid crazy speeds like more than 20 over the limit, for example. The car assist tech would need to account for where that speed might be necessary for a short sprint to avoid an accident.

So in the end, a greatly reduced accident rate, maybe even to the level of where the rate would be if all cars were autonomous, and where accidents do happen, the human is still responsible. I know this doesn't account for people watching the road even less because they think their car will prevent them from back over a kid or ramming into someone who is stopped. But surely we could come up with something where the car "punishes" drivers who don't pay attention and rewards those who do. :)

With respect, no, these are two separate problems:

1) What should we do to save lives by preventing car related accidents.
2) How driverless cars ought to respond to situations in which choices must be made; choices that require some sort of ethical question.

Suppose for the sake of example that we choose for ourselves a utilitarian-like ethical framework. Under such a framework, we can argue that self-driving cars could indeed help with problem (1). As pointed out in the video, these cars have the potential to practically eliminate human errors. This point I support.

However, one does not escape (2) by appealing to (1). The question of 'how' our cars should be programmed to make ethical decisions - perhaps between killing the driver, hitting the motorcyclist, or careening into the family sedan - remains a priority. Since we face the rise of AI, it is more important than ever that we continue to ask what we would like this AI to be like.

To avoid a head-on collision at highway speeds.

Machines are much better than humans at detecting problems before they happen.

Autonomous transportation vehicles work very well when they either 'Ride-On-The-Rails' or if (like airplanes) they are constrained by a traffic control system to occupy precise locations and velocities.

The current construction and use of highways and streets do not meet either of these models.

Autonomous cars will not have arrived unless they are engineered to behave more like airplanes and trains. This does not mean that they will necessarily lose any of their utility. For example new algorithms that allow 'swarms' of autonomous machines to behave in such a way that they do not interfere with each other can, when perfected, allow autonomous cars to operate correctly. Additionally streets and highways will be engineered to support such machines.

My expectation is that this technology will wind up in every car. What this will mean is that we will not have the option of operating a completely manual car.

Even the concept of ownership of a personal vehicle will gradually go away. If you need to go somewhere you talk to your digital assistant and order a car come fetch you. Additionally an advantage of this way of thinking about personal transportation is the boundary between public and private transportation will start to blur. This blurring will reduce the number of vehicles in use saving resources and energy.

When this is coupled with a more ubiquitious Internet, telepresence and "smart" communities we can really reduce resources and energy associated with transportation.

Is this really the "real" moral dilemma?
Self driving cars are almost undoubtedly safer than human-operated cars, but what you've posed isn't a dilemma of "We need people to adopt this as soon as possible" but "why aren't people buying these new, expensive cars with new technology that is very expensive and only typically present in high-end, expensive cars"

The original dilemma is "Is it safer to use something that appears safer at face value but may hold unseen risks when faced with novel circumstances, and to what end is responsibility devolved upon consigning responsibility to the car? Should the same standards of driver education be held when it may be safer to not assume control over the car, and leave the trust in the car that has been paying attention to the entire surroundings?"

What you have posed here is not a dilemma for the consumer, but a dilemma for the manufacturers to swiftly and decisively implement self-driving capabilities in all of their car models, and for as affordable price as possible to increase the number of safer drivers on the roads.

You cannot, in this type of paid promotional material pose this question effectively, because it is simply not within the power of your viewers to enact these changes. If this were filmed on behalf of those developing self-driving technologies, for the purpose of encouraging exigent adoption of said technologies by designers and manufacturers, or whoever is in charge of the decision, then it would be understandable to pose this as "the real dilemma" but the way you have discussed the issue I feel is unbalanced, and directs the "blame" towards the consumer and the legislator, when in fact it is a simple reality that the cars are too expensive for all 430,000 of those who are at risk of injury to travel in a self-driving car.

Edit - Tl;dr: Yes, everyone agrees it's better, but the problem is that not enough affordable self-driving cars are being produced.
